member.name: T:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer
member.summary: A ModPlayer instance represents an extension of a Player instance. You can store fields in the ModPlayer classes, much like how the Player class abuses field usage, to keep track of mod-specific information on the player that a ModPlayer instance represents. It also contains hooks to insert your code into the Player class.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.Player
member.summary: The Player instance that this ModPlayer instance is attached to.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.Initialize
member.summary: Called whenever the player is loaded (on the player selection screen). This can be used to initialize data structures, etc.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.ResetEffects
member.summary: This is where you reset any fields you add to your ModPlayer subclass to their default states. This is necessary in order to reset your fields if they are conditionally set by a tick update but the condition is no longer satisfied.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.UpdateDead
member.summary: Similar to UpdateDead, except this is only called when the player is dead. If this is called, then ResetEffects will not be called.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.PreSaveCustomData
member.summary: Currently never gets called, so this is useless.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.SaveData(Terraria.ModLoader.IO.TagCompound)
member.summary:
Allows you to save custom data for this player.
NOTE: The provided tag is always empty by default, and is provided as an argument only for the sake of convenience and optimization.
NOTE: Try to only save data that isn't default values.
member.param: The TagCompound to save data into. Note that this is always empty by default, and is provided as an argument only for the sake of convenience and optimization.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.LoadData(Terraria.ModLoader.IO.TagCompound)
member.summary:
Allows you to load custom data that you have saved for this player.
Try to write defensive loading code that won't crash if something's missing.
member.param: The TagCompound to load data from.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.PreSavePlayer
member.summary: PreSavePlayer and PostSavePlayer wrap the vanilla player saving code (both are before the ModPlayer.Save). Useful for advanced situations where a save might be corrupted or rendered unusable by the values that normally would save.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.PostSavePlayer
member.summary: PreSavePlayer and PostSavePlayer wrap the vanilla player saving code (both are before the ModPlayer.Save). Useful for advanced situations where a save might be corrupted or rendered unusable by the values that normally would save.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.clientClone(Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer)
member.summary: Allows you to copy information about this player to the clientClone parameter. You should copy information that you intend to sync between server and client. This hook is called in the Player.clientClone method. See SendClientChanges for more info.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.SyncPlayer(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Allows you to sync information about this player between server and client. The toWho and fromWho parameters correspond to the remoteClient/toClient and ignoreClient arguments, respectively, of NetMessage.SendData/ModPacket.Send. The newPlayer parameter is whether or not the player is joining the server (it is true on the joining client).

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.SendClientChanges(Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer)
member.summary: Allows you to sync any information that has changed between the server and client. Here, you should check the information you have copied in the clientClone parameter; if they differ between this player and the clientPlayer parameter, then you should send that information using NetMessage.SendData or ModPacket.Send.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.UpdateBadLifeRegen
member.summary: Allows you to give the player a negative life regeneration based on its state (for example, the "On Fire!" debuff makes the player take damage-over-time). This is typically done by setting Player.lifeRegen to 0 if it is positive, setting Player.lifeRegenTime to 0, and subtracting a number from Player.lifeRegen. The player will take damage at a rate of half the number you subtract per second.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.UpdateLifeRegen
member.summary: Allows you to increase the player's life regeneration based on its state. This can be done by incrementing Player.lifeRegen by a certain number. The player will recover life at a rate of half the number you add per second. You can also increment Player.lifeRegenTime to increase the speed at which the player reaches its maximum natural life regeneration.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.NaturalLifeRegen(System.Single@)
member.summary: Allows you to modify the power of the player's natural life regeneration. This can be done by multiplying the regen parameter by any number. For example, campfires multiply it by 1.1, while walking multiplies it by 0.5.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.UpdateAutopause
member.summary: Allows you to modify the player's stats while the game is paused due to the autopause setting being on. This is called in single player only, some time before the player's tick update would happen when the game isn't paused.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.PreUpdate
member.summary: This is called at the beginning of every tick update for this player, after checking whether the player exists.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.ProcessTriggers(Terraria.GameInput.TriggersSet)
member.summary: Use this to check on keybinds you have registered. While SetControls is set even while in text entry mode, this hook is only called during gameplay.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.SetControls
member.summary: Use this to modify the control inputs that the player receives. For example, the Confused debuff swaps the values of Player.controlLeft and Player.controlRight. This is called sometime after PreUpdate is called.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.PreUpdateBuffs
member.summary: This is called sometime after SetControls is called, and right before all the buffs update on this player. This hook can be used to add buffs to the player based on the player's state (for example, the Campfire buff is added if the player is near a Campfire).

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.PostUpdateBuffs
member.summary: This is called right after all of this player's buffs update on the player. This can be used to modify the effects that the buff updates had on this player, and can also be used for general update tasks.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.UpdateEquips
member.summary: Called after Update Accessories.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.PostUpdateEquips
member.summary: This is called right after all of this player's equipment and armor sets update on the player, which is sometime after PostUpdateBuffs is called. This can be used to modify the effects that the equipment had on this player, and can also be used for general update tasks.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.UpdateVisibleAccessories
member.summary: Is called in Player.Frame() after vanilla functional slots are evaluated, including selection screen to prepare and denote visible accessories. Player Instance sensitive.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.UpdateVisibleVanityAccessories
member.summary: Is called in Player.Frame() after vanilla vanity slots are evaluated, including selection screen to prepare and denote visible accessories. Player Instance sensitive.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.UpdateDyes
member.summary: Is called in Player.UpdateDyes(), including selection screen. Player Instance sensitive.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.PostUpdateMiscEffects
member.summary: This is called after miscellaneous update code is called in Player.Update, which is sometime after PostUpdateEquips is called. This can be used for general update tasks.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.PostUpdateRunSpeeds
member.summary: This is called after the player's horizontal speeds are modified, which is sometime after PostUpdateMiscEffects is called, and right before the player's horizontal position is updated. Use this to modify maxRunSpeed, accRunSpeed, runAcceleration, and similar variables before the player moves forwards/backwards.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.PreUpdateMovement
member.summary: This is called right before modifying the player's position based on velocity. Use this to make direct changes to the velocity.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.PostUpdate
member.summary: This is called at the very end of the Player.Update method. Final general update tasks can be placed here.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.FrameEffects
member.summary: Allows you to modify the armor and accessories that visually appear on the player. In addition, you can create special effects around this character, such as creating dust.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.PreHurt(System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Int32@,System.Int32@,System.Boolean@,System.Boolean@,System.Boolean@,System.Boolean@,Terraria.DataStructures.PlayerDeathReason@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: This hook is called before every time the player takes damage. The pvp parameter is whether the damage was from another player. The quiet parameter determines whether the damage will be communicated to the server. The damage, hitDirection, and crit parameters can be modified. Set the customDamage parameter to true if you want to use your own damage formula (this parameter will disable automatically subtracting the player's defense from the damage). Set the playSound parameter to false to disable the player's hurt sound, and the genGore parameter to false to disable the dust particles that spawn. (These are useful for creating your own sound or gore.) The deathText parameter can be modified to change the player's death message if the player dies. Return false to stop the player from taking damage. Returns true by default.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.Hurt(System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Double,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Int32)
member.summary: Allows you to make anything happen right before damage is subtracted from the player's health.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.PostHurt(System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Double,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Int32)
member.summary: Allows you to make anything happen when the player takes damage.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.PreKill(System.Double,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Boolean@,System.Boolean@,Terraria.DataStructures.PlayerDeathReason@)
member.summary: This hook is called whenever the player is about to be killed after reaching 0 health. Set the playSound parameter to false to stop the death sound from playing. Set the genGore parameter to false to stop the gore and dust from being created. (These are useful for creating your own sound or gore.) Return false to stop the player from being killed. Only return false if you know what you are doing! Returns true by default.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.Kill(System.Double,System.Int32,System.Boolean,Terraria.DataStructures.PlayerDeathReason)
member.summary: Allows you to make anything happen when the player dies.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.PreModifyLuck(System.Single@)
member.summary: Called before vanilla makes any luck calculations. Return false to prevent vanilla from making their luck calculations. Returns true by default.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.ModifyLuck(System.Single@)
member.summary: Allows you to modify a player's luck amount.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.PreItemCheck
member.summary: Allows you to do anything before the update code for the player's held item is run. Return false to stop the held item update code from being run (for example, if the player is frozen). Returns true by default.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.PostItemCheck
member.summary: Allows you to do anything after the update code for the player's held item is run. Hooks for the middle of the held item update code have more specific names in ModItem and ModPlayer.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.UseTimeMultiplier(Terraria.Item)
member.summary:
Allows you to change the effective useTime of an item.
Note that this hook may cause items' actions to run less or more times than they should per a single use.
member.returns: The multiplier on the usage time. 1f by default. Values greater than 1 increase the item use's length.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.UseAnimationMultiplier(Terraria.Item)
member.summary:
Allows you to change the effective useAnimation of an item.
Note that this hook may cause items' actions to run less or more times than they should per a single use.
member.returns: The multiplier on the animation time. 1f by default. Values greater than 1 increase the item animation's length.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.UseSpeedMultiplier(Terraria.Item)
member.summary:
Allows you to safely change both useTime and useAnimation while keeping the values relative to each other.
Useful for status effects.
member.returns: The multiplier on the use speed. 1f by default. Values greater than 1 increase the overall item speed.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.GetHealLife(Terraria.Item,System.Boolean,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Allows you to temporarily modify the amount of life a life healing item will heal for, based on player buffs, accessories, etc. This is only called for items with a healLife value.
member.param: The item.
Whether the item is being used through quick heal or not.
The amount of life being healed.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.GetHealMana(Terraria.Item,System.Boolean,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Allows you to temporarily modify the amount of mana a mana healing item will heal for, based on player buffs, accessories, etc. This is only called for items with a healMana value.
member.param: The item.
Whether the item is being used through quick heal or not.
The amount of mana being healed.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.ModifyManaCost(Terraria.Item,System.Single@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Allows you to temporarily modify the amount of mana an item will consume on use, based on player buffs, accessories, etc. This is only called for items with a mana value.
member.param: The item being used.
Used for decreasingly stacking buffs (most common). Only ever use -= on this field.
Use to directly multiply the item's effective mana cost. Good for debuffs, or things which should stack separately (eg meteor armor set bonus).

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.OnMissingMana(Terraria.Item,System.Int32)
member.summary: Allows you to make stuff happen when a player doesn't have enough mana for the item they are trying to use. If the player has high enough mana after this hook runs, mana consumption will happen normally. Only runs once per item use.
member.param: The item being used.
The mana needed to use the item.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.OnConsumeMana(Terraria.Item,System.Int32)
member.summary: Allows you to make stuff happen when a player consumes mana on use of an item.
member.param: The item being used.
The mana consumed from the player.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.ModifyWeaponDamage(Terraria.Item,Terraria.ModLoader.StatModifier@)
member.summary: Allows you to dynamically modify a weapon's damage based on player and item conditions. Can be utilized to modify damage beyond the tools that DamageClass has to offer.
member.param: The item being used.
The StatModifier object representing the totality of the various modifiers to be applied to the item's base damage.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.ModifyWeaponKnockback(Terraria.Item,Terraria.ModLoader.StatModifier@)
member.summary: Allows you to dynamically modify a weapon's knockback based on player and item conditions. Can be utilized to modify damage beyond the tools that DamageClass has to offer.
member.param: The item being used.
The StatModifier object representing the totality of the various modifiers to be applied to the item's base knockback.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.ModifyWeaponCrit(Terraria.Item,System.Single@)
member.summary: Allows you to dynamically modify a weapon's crit chance based on player and item conditions. Can be utilized to modify damage beyond the tools that DamageClass has to offer.
member.param: The item.
The total crit chance of the item after all normal crit chance calculations.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.CanConsumeAmmo(Terraria.Item,Terraria.Item)
member.summary:
Whether or not the given ammo item will be consumed by this weapon.
By default, returns true; return false to prevent ammo consumption.
If false is returned, the hook is never called.
member.param: The weapon that this player is attempting to use.
The ammo that the give nweapon is attempting to consume.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.OnConsumeAmmo(Terraria.Item,Terraria.Item)
member.summary:
Allows you to make things happen when the given ammo is consumed by the given weapon.
Called before the ammo stack is reduced, and is never called if the ammo isn't consumed in the first place.
member.param: The weapon that is currently using the given ammo.
The ammo that the given weapon is currently using.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.CanShoot(Terraria.Item)
member.summary: Allows you to prevent an item from shooting a projectile on use. Returns true by default.
member.param: The item being used.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.ModifyShootStats(Terraria.Item,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector2@,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector2@,System.Int32@,System.Int32@,System.Single@)

The center position of the projectile.
The velocity of the projectile.

The damage of the projectile.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.Shoot(Terraria.Item,Terraria.DataStructures.EntitySource_ItemUse_WithAmmo,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector2,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector2,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single)

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.MeleeEffects(Terraria.Item,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Rectangle)
member.summary: Allows you to give this player's melee weapon special effects, such as creating light or dust.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.CanCatchNPC(Terraria.NPC,Terraria.Item)
member.summary:
Allows you to determine whether the given item can catch the given NPC.
Return true or false to say the target can or cannot be caught, respectively, regardless of vanilla rules.
Returns null by default, which allows vanilla's NPC catching rules to decide the target's fate.
If this returns false, is never called.
NOTE: this does not classify the given item as a catch tool, which is necessary for catching NPCs in the first place.
To do that, you will need to use the "CatchingTool" set in ItemID.Sets.
member.param: The NPC the player is trying to catch.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.ModifyFishingAttempt(Terraria.DataStructures.FishingAttempt@)
member.summary:
Allows you to change information about the ongoing fishing attempt before cought items/NPCs are decided, after all vanilla information has been gathered.
Will not be called if various conditions for getting a catch aren't met, meaning you can't modify those.
Setting or is not allowed and will be reset, use for that.
member.param: The structure containing most data from the vanilla fishing attempt

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.CatchFish(Terraria.DataStructures.FishingAttempt,System.Int32@,System.Int32@,Terraria.AdvancedPopupRequest@,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector2@)
member.summary: Allows you to change the item or enemy the player gets when sucessfully catching an item or NPC. The Fishing Attempt structure contains most information about the vanilla event, including the Item Rod and Bait used by the player, the liquid it is being fished on, and so on. The Sonar and Sonar position fields allow you to change the text, color, velocity and position of the catch's name (be it item or NPC) freely
member.param: The structure containing most data from the vanilla fishing attempt
The item that will be created when this fishing attempt succeeds. leave <0 for no item
The enemy that will be spawned if there is no item caught. leave <0 for no NPC spawn
Fill all of this structure's fields to override the sonar text, or make sonar.Text null to disable custom sonar
The position the Sonar text will spawn. Bobber location by default.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.ModifyCaughtFish(Terraria.Item)
member.summary: Allows you to modify the item caught by the fishing player, including stack
member.param: The item (Fish) to modify

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.CanConsumeBait(Terraria.Item)
member.summary: Choose if this bait will be consumed or not when used for fishing. return null for vanilla behaviour. Not consuming will always take priority over forced consumption
member.param: The item (bait) that would be consumed

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.GetFishingLevel(Terraria.Item,Terraria.Item,System.Single@)
member.summary: Allows you to modify the player's fishing power. As an example of the type of stuff that should go here, the phase of the moon can influence fishing power.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.AnglerQuestReward(System.Single,System.Collections.Generic.List{Terraria.Item})
member.summary: Allows you to add to, change, or remove from the items the player earns when finishing an Angler quest. The rareMultiplier is a number between 0.15 and 1 inclusively; the lower it is the higher chance there should be for the player to earn rare items.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.GetDyeTraderReward(System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Int32})
member.summary: Allows you to modify what items are possible for the player to earn when giving a Strange Plant to the Dye Trader.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.DrawEffects(Terraria.DataStructures.PlayerDrawSet,System.Single@,System.Single@,System.Single@,System.Single@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary:
Allows you to create special effects when this player is drawn, such as creating dust, modifying the color the player is drawn in, etc. The fullBright parameter makes it so that the drawn player ignores the modified color and lighting. Note that the fullBright parameter only works if r, g, b, and/or a is not equal to 1. Make sure to add the indexes of any dusts you create to drawInfo.DustCache, and the indexes of any gore you create to drawInfo.GoreCache.
This will be called multiple times a frame if a player afterimage is being drawn. Check if(drawinfo.shadow == 0f) to do some logic only when drawing the original player image. For example, spawning dust only for the original player image is commonly the desired behavior.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.ModifyDrawInfo(Terraria.DataStructures.PlayerDrawSet@)
member.summary: Allows you to modify the drawing parameters of the player before drawing begins.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.ModifyDrawLayerOrdering(System.Collections.Generic.IDictionary{Terraria.ModLoader.PlayerDrawLayer,Terraria.ModLoader.PlayerDrawLayer.Position})
member.summary: Allows you to reorder the player draw layers. This is called once at the end of mod loading, not during the game. Use with extreme caution, or risk breaking other mods.
member.param: Add/remove/change the positions applied to each layer here

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.HideDrawLayers(Terraria.DataStructures.PlayerDrawSet)
member.summary: Allows you to modify the visibility of layers about to be drawn

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.ModifyScreenPosition
member.summary: Use this hook to modify Main.screenPosition after weapon zoom and camera lerp have taken place.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.ModifyZoom(System.Single@)
member.summary: Use this to modify the zoom factor for the player. The zoom correlates to the percentage of half the screen size the zoom can reach. A value of -1 passed in means no vanilla scope is in effect. A value of 1.0 means the scope can zoom half a screen width/height away, putting the player on the edge of the game screen. Vanilla values include .8, .6666, and .5.

member.param: The Nurse NPC instance.
How much health the player gains.
If set to false, debuffs will not be healed.
Set this to the Nurse chat text that will display if healing is prevented.

How much health the player gains.
Whether or not debuffs will be healed.

members.member:
Called on the Client after the player heals themselves with the Nurse NPC.
The Nurse npc providing the heal. How much health the player gained. /// Whether or not debuffs were healed. The price the player paid in copper coins.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPlayer.AddStartingItems(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Called when the player is created in the menu. You can use this method to add items to the player's starting inventory, as well as their inventory when they respawn in mediumcore.

member.summary: Allows you to modify the items that will be added to the player's inventory. Useful if you want to stop vanilla or other mods from adding an item. You can access a mod's items by using the mod's internal name as the indexer, such as: additions["ModName"]. To access vanilla items you can use "Terraria" as the index.
member.param: The items that will be added. Each key is the internal mod name of the mod adding the items. Vanilla items use the "Terraria" key.
Whether you are setting up a mediumcore player's inventory after their death.

member.name: T:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile
member.summary:
This class serves as a place for you to place all your properties and hooks for each projectile. Create instances of ModProjectile (preferably overriding this class) to pass as parameters to Mod.AddProjectile.
The Basic Projectile Guide teaches the basics of making a modded projectile.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.Projectile
member.summary: The projectile object that this ModProjectile controls.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.Type
member.summary: Shorthand for Projectile.type;

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.DisplayName
member.summary: The translations for the display name of this projectile.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.AIType
member.summary: Determines which type of vanilla projectile this ModProjectile will copy the behavior (AI) of. Leave as 0 to not copy any behavior. Defaults to 0.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.CooldownSlot
member.summary: Determines which () to use when this projectile damages a player. Defaults to -1.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.DrawOffsetX
member.summary: How far to the right of its position this projectile should be drawn. Defaults to 0.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.DrawOriginOffsetY
member.summary: The vertical origin offset from the projectile's center when it is drawn. The origin is essentially the point of rotation. This field will also determine the vertical drawing offset of the projectile.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.DrawOriginOffsetX
member.summary: The horizontal origin offset from the projectile's center when it is drawn.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.DrawHeldProjInFrontOfHeldItemAndArms
member.summary: If this projectile is held by the player, determines whether it is drawn in front of or behind the player's arms. Defaults to false.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.Texture
member.summary: The file name of this type's texture file in the mod loader's file space.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.GlowTexture
member.summary: The file name of this projectile's glow texture file in the mod loader's file space. If it does not exist it is ignored.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.SetDefaults
member.summary: Allows you to set all your projectile's properties, such as width, damage, aiStyle, penetrate, etc.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.OnSpawn(Terraria.DataStructures.IEntitySource)
member.summary: Gets called when your projectiles spawns in world

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.AutoStaticDefaults
member.summary: Automatically sets certain static defaults. Override this if you do not want the properties to be set for you.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.PreAI
member.summary: Allows you to determine how this projectile behaves. Return false to stop the vanilla AI and the AI hook from being run. Returns true by default.
member.returns: Whether or not to stop other AI.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.AI
member.summary: Allows you to determine how this projectile behaves. This will only be called if PreAI returns true.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.PostAI
member.summary: Allows you to determine how this projectile behaves. This will be called regardless of what PreAI returns.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.SendExtraAI(System.IO.BinaryWriter)
member.summary:
If you are storing AI information outside of the Projectile.ai array, use this to send that AI information between clients and servers, which will be handled in .
Called whenever is successfully sent, for example on projectile creation, or whenever Projectile.netUpdate is set to true in the update loop for that tick.
Can be called on both server and client, depending on who owns the projectile.
member.param: The writer.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.ReceiveExtraAI(System.IO.BinaryReader)
member.summary:
Use this to receive information that was sent in .
Called whenever is successfully received.
Can be called on both server and client, depending on who owns the projectile.
member.param: The reader.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.ShouldUpdatePosition
member.summary: Whether or not this projectile should update its position based on factors such as its velocity, whether it is in liquid, etc. Return false to make its velocity have no effect on its position. Returns true by default.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.TileCollideStyle(System.Int32@,System.Int32@,System.Boolean@,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector2@)
member.summary: Allows you to determine how this projectile interacts with tiles. Return false if you completely override or cancel this projectile's tile collision behavior. Returns true by default.
member.param: The width of the hitbox this projectile will use for tile collision. If vanilla doesn't modify it, defaults to Projectile.width.
The height of the hitbox this projectile will use for tile collision. If vanilla doesn't modify it, defaults to Projectile.height.
Whether or not this projectile falls through platforms and similar tiles.

Determines by how much the tile collision hitbox's position (top left corner) will be offset from this projectile's real center. If vanilla doesn't modify it, defaults to half the hitbox size (new Vector2(0.5f, 0.5f)).

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.OnTileCollide(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector2)
member.summary: Allows you to determine what happens when this projectile collides with a tile. OldVelocity is the velocity before tile collision. The velocity that takes tile collision into account can be found with Projectile.velocity. Return true to allow the vanilla tile collision code to take place (which normally kills the projectile). Returns true by default.
member.param: The velocity of the projectile upon collision.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.CanCutTiles
member.summary: Return true or false to specify if the projectile can cut tiles like vines, pots, and Queen Bee larva. Return null for vanilla decision.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.CutTiles
member.summary: Code ran when the projectile cuts tiles. Only runs if CanCutTiles() returns true. Useful when programming lasers and such.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.PreKill(System.Int32)
member.summary: Allows you to determine whether the vanilla code for Kill and the Kill hook will be called. Return false to stop them from being called. Returns true by default. Note that this does not stop the projectile from dying.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.Kill(System.Int32)
member.summary: Allows you to control what happens when this projectile is killed (for example, creating dust or making sounds). Also useful for creating retrievable ammo. Called on all clients and the server in multiplayer, so be sure to use `if (Projectile.owner == Main.myPlayer)` if you are spawning retrievable ammo. (As seen in ExampleJavelinProjectile)

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.CanDamage
member.summary: Whether or not this projectile is capable of killing tiles (such as grass) and damaging NPCs/players. Return false to prevent it from doing any sort of damage. Return true if you want the projectile to do damage regardless of the default blacklist. Return null to let the projectile follow vanilla can-damage-anything rules. This is what happens by default.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.MinionContactDamage
member.summary: Whether or not this minion can damage NPCs by touching them. Returns false by default. Note that this will only be used if this projectile is considered a pet.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.ModifyDamageHitbox(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Rectangle@)
member.summary: Allows you to change the hitbox used by this projectile for damaging players and NPCs.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.ModifyDamageScaling(System.Single@)
member.summary: Allows you to implement dynamic damage scaling for this projectile. For example, flails do more damage when in flight and Jousting Lance does more damage the faster the player is moving. This hook runs on the owner only.
member.param: The damage scaling

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.CanHitNPC(Terraria.NPC)
member.summary: Allows you to determine whether this projectile can hit the given NPC. Return true to allow hitting the target, return false to block this projectile from hitting the target, and return null to use the vanilla code for whether the target can be hit. Returns null by default.
member.param: The target.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModProjectile.ModifyHitNPC(Terraria.NPC,System.Int32@,System.Single@,System.Boolean@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Allows you to modify the damage, knockback, etc., that this projectile does to an NPC. This method is only called for the owner of the projectile, meaning that in multi-player, projectiles owned by a player call this method on that client, and projectiles owned by the server such as enemy projectiles call this method on the server.
member.param: The target.

member.name: T:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPylon
member.summary: Extension to that streamlines the process of creating a modded Pylon. Has all of ModTile's hooks for customization, but additional hooks for Pylon functionality.
member.remarks:
One of the key features of this class is the ValidTeleportCheck process. At first glance it can look a bit messy, however here is a rough break-down of the call process to help you if you're lost:
1) Game queries if the specified player is near a Pylon ()
2) Assuming Step 1 has passed, game queries if the DESTINATION PYLON (the pylon the player CLICKED on the map) has enough NPCs nearby (NPCCount step)
3) Assuming Step 2 has passed, game queries if there is ANY DANGER at ALL across the entire map, ignoring the lunar pillar event (AnyDanger step)
4) Assuming Step 3 has passed, game queries if the DESTINATION PYLON is in the Lihzahrd Temple before Plantera is defeated.
5) Assuming Step 4 has passed, game queries if the DESTINATION PYLON meets its biome specifications for whatever type of pylon it is (BiomeRequirements step)
6) Regardless of all the past checks, if the DESTINATION PYLON is a modded one, is called on it.
7) The game queries all pylons on the map and checks if any of them are in interaction distance with the player (), and if so, checks Step 2 on it. If Step 2 passes, Step 5 is then called on it as well (NPCCount & BiomeRequirements step). If Step 5 also passes, the loop breaks and no further pylons are checked, and for the next steps, the pylon that succeeded will be the designated NEARBY PYLON.
8) Regardless of all the past checks, if the designated NEARBY PYLON is a modded one, is called on it.
9) Any instances run .
10) Finally, if all previous checks pass AND the DESTINATION pylon is a modded one, is called on it, right before the player is teleported.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPylon.PylonType
member.summary: What type of Pylon this ModPylon represents.
member.remarks: The TeleportPylonType enum only has string names up until Count (9). The very first modded pylon to be added will technically be accessible with the enum type of "Count" since that value isn't an actual "type" of pylon, and modded pylons are assigned IDs starting with the Count value (9). All other modded pylons added after 9 (i.e 10+) will have no enum name, and will only every be referred to by their number values.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPylon.CanPlacePylon
member.summary: Whether or not this Pylon can even be placed. By default, it returns false if a Pylon of this type already exists in the world, otherwise true. If you want to allow an infinite amount of these pylons to be placed, simply always return true.
member.remarks:
Note that in Multiplayer environments, granted that any GlobalPylon instances do not return false in , this is called first on the client, and then is subsequently called & double checked on the server.
If the server disagrees with the client that the given pylon CANNOT be placed for any given reason, the server will reject the placement and subsequently break the associated tile.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPylon.IsPylonForSale(System.Int32,Terraria.Player,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Whether or not this Pylon should be sold by the specified NPC type and with the given player. This should return the ITEM TYPE of the item that places this ModPylon, if one exists. If you don't want anything to be put up for sale, return null.
Returns null by default.
member.param: The type of the NPC currently being spoken to to determine the shop of.
The current player asking said NPC type what they have for sale.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPylon.ValidTeleportCheck_NPCCount(Terraria.GameContent.TeleportPylonInfo,System.Int32)
member.summary: Step 1 of the ValidTeleportCheck process. This is the first vanilla check that is called when checking both the destination pylon and any possible nearby pylons. This check should be where you check how many NPCs are nearby, returning false if the Pylon does not satisfy the conditions. By default, returns true if there are 2 or more NPCs nearby.
member.remarks:
Note that it's important you put the right checks in the right ValidTeleportCheck step, as whatever one returns false (if any) will determine the error message sent to the player.
If you're confused about the order of which the ValidTeleportCheck methods are called, check out the XML summary on the ModPylon class.
member.param: The internal information pertaining to the current pylon being teleported to or from.
The default amount of NPCs nearby required to satisfy a VANILLA pylon.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPylon.ValidTeleportCheck_AnyDanger(Terraria.GameContent.TeleportPylonInfo)
member.summary: Step 2 of the ValidTeleportCheck process. This is the second vanilla check that is called when checking the destination pylon. This check should be where you check if there is any "Danger" nearby, such as bosses or if there is an event happening. It is unlikely you will need to use this. By default, returns true if there are not any events happening (Lunar Pillars do not count) and there are no bosses currently alive.
member.remarks:
Note that it's important you put the right checks in the right ValidTeleportCheck step, as whatever one returns false (if any) will determine the error message sent to the player.
If you're confused about the order of which the ValidTeleportCheck methods are called, check out the XML summary on the ModPylon class.
member.param: The internal information pertaining to the current pylon being teleported TO.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPylon.ValidTeleportCheck_BiomeRequirements(Terraria.GameContent.TeleportPylonInfo,Terraria.SceneMetrics)
member.summary: Step 3 of the ValidTeleportCheck process. This is the fourth vanilla check that is called when checking both the destination pylon and any possible nearby pylons. This check should be where you check biome related things, such as the simple check of whether or not the Pylon is in the proper biome. By default, returns true.
member.remarks:
Note that it's important you put the right checks in the right ValidTeleportCheck step, as whatever one returns false (if any) will determine the error message sent to the player.
If you're confused about the order of which the ValidTeleportCheck methods are called, check out the XML summary on the ModPylon class.
member.param: The internal information pertaining to the current pylon being teleported to or from.
The scene metrics data AT THE LOCATION of the destination pylon, NOT the player.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPylon.ValidTeleportCheck_DestinationPostCheck(Terraria.GameContent.TeleportPylonInfo,System.Boolean@,System.String@)
member.summary:
The 4th check of the ValidTeleportCheck process. This check is for modded Pylons only, called after ALL other checks have completed pertaining the pylon clicked on the map (the destination pylon), but before any nearby pylon information is calculated. This is where you an do custom checks that don't pertain to the past destination checks, as well as customize the localization key to give custom messages to the player on teleportation failure. By default, does nothing.
If you're confused about the order of which the ValidTeleportCheck methods are called, check out the XML summary on the ModPylon class.
member.param: The Pylon information for the Pylon that the player is attempt to teleport to.
Whether or not after all of the checks, the destination Pylon is valid.
The localization key for the message sent to the player if destinationPylonValid is false.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPylon.ValidTeleportCheck_NearbyPostCheck(Terraria.GameContent.TeleportPylonInfo,System.Boolean@,System.Boolean@,System.String@)
member.summary:
The 5th and final check of the ValidTeleportCheck process. This check is for modded Pylons only, called after ALL other checks have completed for the destination pylon and all normal checks have taken place for the nearby pylon, if applicable. This is where you can do custom checks that don't pertain to the past nearby pylon checks, as well as customize the localization key to give custom messages to the player on teleportation failure. By default, does nothing.
If you're confused about the order of which the ValidTeleportCheck methods are called, check out the XML summary on the ModPylon class.
member.param: The pylon information of the pylon the player in question is standing NEAR. This always has a value.
Whether or not after all of the checks, the destination Pylon is valid.
Whether or not after all of the checks, there is a Pylon nearby to the player that is valid.
The localization key for the message sent to the player if destinationPylonValid is false.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModPylon.ModifyTeleportationPosition(Terraria.GameContent.TeleportPylonInfo,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector2@)
member.summary: Called right BEFORE the teleportation of the player occurs, when all checks succeed during the ValidTeleportCheck process. Allows the modification of where the player ends up when the teleportation takes place. Remember that the teleport location is in WORLD coordinates, not tile coordinates.
member.remarks: You shouldn't need to use this method if your pylon is the same size as a normal vanilla pylons (3x4 tiles).
member.param: The information of the pylon the player intends to teleport to.
The position (IN WORLD COORDINATES) of where the player ends up when the teleportation occurs.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModRarity.GetPrefixedRarity(System.Int32,System.Single)

member.name: T:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSceneEffect
member.summary: ModSceneEffect is an abstract class that your classes can derive from. It serves as a container for handling exclusive SceneEffect content such as backgrounds, music, and water styling.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSceneEffect.Priority
member.summary: The of this SceneEffect layer. Determines the relative postion compared to vanilla SceneEffect. Analogously, if SceneEffect were competing in a wrestling match, this would be the 'Weight Class' that this SceneEffect is competing in.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSceneEffect.TileColorStyle
member.summary: Used to apply secondary colour shading for the capture camera. For example, darkening the background with the GlowingMushroom style.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSceneEffect.RegisterSceneEffect(Terraria.ModLoader.ModSceneEffect)
member.summary: Forcefully registers the provided ModSceneEffect to LoaderManager. ModBiome and direct implementations call this. Does NOT cache the return type.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSceneEffect.GetWeight(Terraria.Player)
member.summary: Is invoked when two or more modded SceneEffect layers are active within the same group to attempt to determine which one should take precedence, if it matters. It's uncommon that need to assign a weight - you'd have to specifically believe that you don't need higher SceneEffectPriority, but do need to be the active SceneEffect within the priority you designated Analogously, if SceneEffect were competing in a wrestling match, this would be how likely the SceneEffect should win within its weight class. Is intentionally bounded at a max of 100% (1) to reduce complexity. Defaults to 50% (0.5). Typical calculations may include: 1) how many tiles are present as a percentage of target amount; 2) how far away you are from the cause of the SceneEffect

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSceneEffect.GetCorrWeight(Terraria.Player)
member.summary: Combines Priority and Weight to determine what SceneEffect should be active. Priority is used to do primary sorting with respect to vanilla SceneEffect. Weight will be used if multiple SceneEffect have the same SceneEffectPriority so as to attempt to distinguish them based on their needs.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSceneEffect.SpecialVisuals(Terraria.Player,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Allows you to create special visual effects in the area around the player. For example, the blood moon's red filter on the screen or the slime rain's falling slime in the background. You must create classes that override Terraria.Graphics.Shaders.ScreenShaderData or Terraria.Graphics.Effects.CustomSky, add them in your mod's Load hook, then call Player.ManageSpecialBiomeVisuals. See the ExampleMod if you do not have access to the source code.

member.name: T:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSide
member.summary: A ModSide enum defines how mods are synced between clients and servers. You can set your mod's ModSide from its build.txt file.

member.name: F:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSide.Both
member.summary: The default value for ModSide. This means that the mod has effects both client-side and server-side. When a client connects to a server, this mod will be disabled if the server does not have it. If a client without this mod connects to a server with this mod, the server will send this mod to the client and enable it. In general all mods that add game content should use this.

member.name: F:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSide.Client
member.summary: This means that the mod only has effects client-side. This mod will not be disabled client-side if the server does not have it. This is useful for mods that only add controls (for example, keybinds), change textures/musics, etc.

member.name: F:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSide.Server
member.summary: This means that the mod only has effects server-side. The server will not send this mod to every client that connects.

member.name: F:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSide.NoSync
member.summary: This means that the mod could have effects client-side and could have effects server-side. The client will not download this mod if it connects to a server with this mod, and the client will not disable this mod if it connects to a server without this mod. If a client connects to a server and both have this mod, then IDs will still be synchronized. This is useful if you want optional extra features when both the client and server have this mod.

member.name: T:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem
member.summary: ModSystem is an abstract class that your classes can derive from. It contains general-use hooks, and, unlike Mod, can have unlimited amounts of types deriving from it.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.SetupContent
member.summary: Unlike other ModTypes, SetupContent is unsealed for you to do whatever you need. By default it just calls SetStaticDefaults. This is the place to finish initializing your mod's content. For content from other mods, and lookup tables, consider PostSetupContent

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.OnModLoad
member.summary: This hook is called right after Mod.Load(), which is guaranteed to be called after all content has been autoloaded.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.OnModUnload
member.summary: This hook is called right before Mod.UnLoad()

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.PostSetupContent
member.summary: Allows you to load things in your system after the mod's content has been setup (arrays have been resized to fit the content, etc).

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.AddRecipes
member.summary:
Override this method to add recipes to the game.
It is recommended that you do so through instances of Recipe, since it provides methods that simplify recipe creation.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.PostAddRecipes
member.summary:
This provides a hook into the mod-loading process immediately after recipes have been added.
You can use this to edit recipes added by other mods.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.PostSetupRecipes
member.summary: Override this method to do treatment about recipes once they have been setup. You shouldn't edit any recipe here.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.AddRecipeGroups
member.summary:
Override this method to add recipe groups to the game.
You must add recipe groups by calling the method here.
A recipe group is a set of items that can be used interchangeably in the same recipe.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.OnWorldLoad
member.summary:
Called whenever a world is loaded. This can be used to initialize data structures, etc.
If you need to access your data during worldgen, initialize it in instead, unless you also save it on the world, then you need both.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.OnWorldUnload
member.summary: Called whenever a world is unloaded. Use this to deinitialize world-related data structures, etc.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.ModifyScreenPosition
member.summary: Use this hook to modify Main.screenPosition after weapon zoom and camera lerp have taken place.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.ModifyTransformMatrix(Terraria.Graphics.SpriteViewMatrix@)
member.summary: Allows you to set the transformation of the screen that is drawn. (Translations, rotations, scales, etc.)

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.UpdateUI(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GameTime)
member.summary: Ran every update and suitable for calling Update for UserInterface classes

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.PreUpdateEntities
member.summary:
Use this if you want to do something before anything in the World gets updated. Called after UI updates, but before anything in the World (Players, NPCs, Projectiles, Tiles) gets updated.
When is true or is 0 or 2, the game may do a partial update. This means that it only updates menus and some animations, but not the World or Entities. This hook - and every hook after it - only gets called on frames with a full update.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.PreUpdatePlayers

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.PostUpdatePlayers
member.summary: Called after Players get updated.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.PostUpdateNPCs
member.summary: Called after NPCs get updated.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.PostUpdateGores
member.summary: Called after Gores get updated.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.PreUpdateTime
member.summary: Called before Time gets updated.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.PostUpdateTime
member.summary: Called after Time gets updated.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.PreUpdateWorld
member.summary:
Use this method to have things happen in the world. In vanilla Terraria, a good example of code suitable for this hook is how Falling Stars fall to the ground during the night.
This hook is not called for multiplayer clients.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.PostUpdateWorld
member.summary:
Use this method to have things happen in the world. In vanilla Terraria, a good example of code suitable for this hook is how Falling Stars fall to the ground during the night.
This hook is not called for multiplayer clients.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.PreUpdateInvasions
member.summary:
Called before Invasions get updated.
This hook is not called for multiplayer clients.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.PostUpdateInvasions
member.summary:
Called after Invasions get updated.
This hook is not called for multiplayer clients.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.PostUpdateEverything
member.summary: Called after the Network got updated, this is the last hook that happens in an update.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.ModifyInterfaceLayers(System.Collections.Generic.List{Terraria.UI.GameInterfaceLayer})
member.summary: Allows you to modify the elements of the in-game interface that get drawn. GameInterfaceLayer can be found in the Terraria.UI namespace. Check https://github.com/tModLoader/tModLoader/wiki/Vanilla-Interface-layers-values for vanilla interface layer names
member.param: The layers.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.ModifyGameTipVisibility(System.Collections.Generic.IReadOnlyList{Terraria.ModLoader.GameTipData})
member.summary: Allows you to set the visibility of any added vanilla or modded GameTips. In order to add your OWN tips, add them in your localization file, with the key prefix of "Mods.ModName.GameTips".
member.param: The current list of all added game tips.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.PostDrawInterface(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteBatch)
member.summary:
Called after interface is drawn but right before mouse and mouse hover text is drawn. Allows for drawing interface.
Note: This hook should no longer be used. It is better to use the ModifyInterfaceLayers hook.
member.param: The sprite batch.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.PreDrawMapIconOverlay(System.Collections.Generic.IReadOnlyList{Terraria.Map.IMapLayer},Terraria.Map.MapOverlayDrawContext)
member.summary: Called right before map icon overlays are drawn. Use this hook to selectively hide existing or

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.PostDrawFullscreenMap(System.String@)
member.summary: Called while the fullscreen map is active. Allows custom drawing to the map. Using is more compatible and allows drawing on the minimap and fullscreen maps.
member.param: The mouse text.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.PostUpdateInput
member.summary: Called after the input keys are polled. Allows for modifying things like scroll wheel if your custom drawing should capture that.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.PreSaveAndQuit
member.summary: Called in SP or Client when the Save and Quit button is pressed. One use for this hook is clearing out custom UI slots to return items to the player.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.PostDrawTiles
member.summary: Called after drawing Tiles. Can be used for drawing a tile overlay akin to wires. Note that spritebatch should be begun and ended within this method.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.ModifyTimeRate(System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Called after all other time calculations. Can be used to modify the speed at which time should progress per tick in seconds, along with the rate at which the tiles in the world and the events in the world should update with it. All fields are measured in in-game minutes per real-life second (min/sec). You may want to consider and CreativePowerManager.Instance.GetPower<CreativePowers.FreezeTime>().Enabled here.
member.param: The speed at which time flows in min/sec.
The speed at which tiles in the world update in min/sec.
The speed at which various events in the world (weather changes, fallen star/fairy spawns, etc.) update in min/sec.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.SaveWorldData(Terraria.ModLoader.IO.TagCompound)
member.summary:
Allows you to save custom data for this system in the current world. Useful for things like saving world specific flags.
For example, if your mod adds a boss and you want certain NPC to only spawn once it has been defeated, this is where you would store the information that that boss has been defeated in this world.
NOTE: The provided tag is always empty by default, and is provided as an argument only for the sake of convenience and optimization.
NOTE: Try to only save data that isn't default values.
member.param: The TagCompound to save data into. Note that this is always empty by default, and is provided as an argument only for the sake of convenience and optimization.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.LoadWorldData(Terraria.ModLoader.IO.TagCompound)
member.summary:
Allows you to load custom data you have saved for this system in the currently loading world.
Try to write defensive loading code that won't crash if something's missing.
member.param: The TagCompound to load data from.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.CanWorldBePlayed(Terraria.IO.PlayerFileData,Terraria.IO.WorldFileData)
member.summary: Allows you to prevent the world and player from being loaded/selected as a valid combination, similar to Journey Mode pairing.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.NetSend(System.IO.BinaryWriter)
member.summary:
Allows you to send custom data between clients and server, which will be handled in . This is useful for syncing information such as bosses that have been defeated.
Called whenever is successfully sent, for example after a boss is defeated, a new day starts, or a player joins the server.
Only called on the server.
member.param: The writer.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.NetReceive(System.IO.BinaryReader)
member.summary:
Use this to receive information that was sent in .
Called whenever is successfully received.
Only called on the client.
member.param: The reader.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.HijackGetData(System.Byte@,System.IO.BinaryReader@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Allows you to modify net message / packet information that is received before the game can act on it.
member.param: Type of the message.
The reader.
The player number the message is from.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.HijackSendData(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Terraria.Localization.NetworkText,System.Int32,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Hijacks the send data method. Only use if you absolutely know what you are doing. If any hooks return true, the message is not sent.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.PreWorldGen
member.summary:
Allows a mod to run code before a world is generated.
If you use this to initialize data used during worldgen, which you save on the world, also initialize it in .

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.ModifyWorldGenTasks(System.Collections.Generic.List{Terraria.WorldBuilding.GenPass},System.Single@)
member.summary:
A more advanced option to PostWorldGen, this method allows you modify the list of Generation Passes before a new world begins to be generated.
For example, removing the "Planting Trees" pass will cause a world to generate without trees. Placing a new Generation Pass before the "Dungeon" pass will prevent the the mod's pass from cutting into the dungeon.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.PostWorldGen
member.summary: Use this method to place tiles in the world after world generation is complete.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.ResetNearbyTileEffects
member.summary: Use this to reset any fields you set in any of your ModTile.NearbyEffects hooks back to their default values.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.ModifyHardmodeTasks(System.Collections.Generic.List{Terraria.WorldBuilding.GenPass})
member.summary: Similar to ModifyWorldGenTasks, but occurs in-game when Hardmode starts. Can be used to modify which tasks should be done and/or add custom tasks. By default the list will only contain 4 items, the vanilla hardmode tasks called "Hardmode Good", "Hardmode Evil", "Hardmode Walls", and "Hardmode Announcment"

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.ModifySunLightColor(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Color@,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Color@)
member.summary: Allows you to modify color of light the sun emits.

Background lighting color

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.ModifyLightingBrightness(System.Single@)
member.summary: Allows you to modify overall brightness of lights. Can be used to create effects similiar to what night vision and darkness (de)buffs give you. Values too high or too low might result in glitches. For night vision effect use scale 1.03
member.param: Brightness scale

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModSystem.TileCountsAvailable(System.ReadOnlySpan{System.Int32})
member.summary:
Allows you to store information about how many of each tile is nearby the player. This is useful for counting how many tiles of a certain custom biome there are.
The parameter is a read-only span (treat this as an array) that stores the tile count indexed by tile type.

member.name: T:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTexturedType
member.summary: The base type for most modded things with textures.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTexturedType.Texture
member.summary: The file name of this type's texture file in the mod loader's file space.

member.name: T:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile
member.summary:
This class represents a type of tile that can be added by a mod. Only one instance of this class will ever exist for each type of tile that is added. Any hooks that are called will be called by the instance corresponding to the tile type. This is to prevent the game from using a massive amount of memory storing tile instances.
The Basic Tile Guide teaches the basics of making a modded tile.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.AnimationFrameHeight
member.summary: The height of a group of animation frames for this tile. Defaults to 0, which disables animations.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.MineResist
member.summary: A multiplier describing how much this block resists harvesting. Higher values will make it take longer to harvest. Defaults to 1f.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.MinPick
member.summary: The minimum pickaxe power required for pickaxes to mine this block. Defaults to 0.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.AdjTiles
member.summary: An array of the IDs of tiles that this tile can be considered as when looking for crafting stations.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.CloseDoorID
member.summary: The ID of the tile that this door transforms into when it is closed. Defaults to -1, which means this tile isn't a door.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.OpenDoorID
member.summary: The ID of the tile that this door transforms into when it is opened. Defaults to -1, which means this tile isn't a door.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.ChestDrop
member.summary: The ID of the item that drops when this chest is destroyed. Defaults to 0. Honestly, this is only really used when the chest limit is reached on a server.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.DresserDrop
member.summary: The ID of the item that drops when this dresser is destroyed. Defaults to 0. Honestly, this is only really used when the chest limit is reached on a server.

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.ContainerName
member.summary: The translations for the name that is displayed when this tile is opened as a chest or dresser. This won't be used if you don't add your tile to or .

member.name: P:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.HighlightTexture
member.summary: The highlight texture used when this tile is selected by smart interact. Defaults to adding "_Highlight" onto the main texture.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.AddToArray(System.Int32[]@)
member.summary: A convenient method for adding this tile's Type to the given array. This can be used with the arrays in TileID.Sets.RoomNeeds.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.ModifySittingTargetInfo(System.Int32,System.Int32,Terraria.DataStructures.TileRestingInfo@)
member.summary:
Modify the parameters for the entity sitting on this furniture tile with its type registered to .
This is also called on NPCs sitting on this tile! To access the entity (player or NPC), use info.restingEntity.
This gets called when calling , when the town NPC decides to sit, and each tick while the player is sitting on a suitable furniture. i and j derived from "(entity.Bottom + new Vector2(0f, -2f)).ToTileCoordinates()" or from the tile coordinates the player clicked on.
Formula: anchorTilePosition.ToWorldCoordinates(8f, 16f) + finalOffset + new Vector2(0, targetDirection * directionOffset).
member.param: The x position in tile coordinates.
The y position in tile coordinates.
The parameters for setting the anchor and offsets. You need to edit this

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.ModifySleepingTargetInfo(System.Int32,System.Int32,Terraria.DataStructures.TileRestingInfo@)
member.summary:
Modify the visual player offset when sleeping on this tile with its type registered to .
This gets called when calling , and each tick while the player is resting in the bed, i and j derived from "(player.Bottom + new Vector2(0f, -2f)).ToTileCoordinates()" or from the tile coordinates the player clicked on.
Formula: new Point(anchorTilePosition.X, anchorTilePosition.Y + 1).ToWorldCoordinates(8f, 16f) + finalOffset + new Vector2(0, targetDirection * directionOffset).
member.param: The x position in tile coordinates.
The y position in tile coordinates.
The parameters for setting the anchor and offsets. Default values match the regular vanilla bed.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.DropCritterChance(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32@,System.Int32@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Allows you to modify the chance the tile at the given coordinates has of spawning a certain critter when the tile is killed.
member.param: The x position in tile coordinates.
The y position in tile coordinates.
Chance for a worm to spawn. Value corresponds to a chance of 1 in X. Vanilla values include: Grass-400, Plants-200, Various Piles-6
Chance for a grass hopper to spawn. Value corresponds to a chance of 1 in X. Vanilla values include: Grass-100, Plants-50
Chance for a jungle grub to spawn. Value corresponds to a chance of 1 in X. Vanilla values include: JungleVines-250, JunglePlants2-40, PlantDetritus-10

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.Drop(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Allows you to customize which items the tile at the given coordinates drops. Remember that the x, y (i, j) coordinates are in tile coordinates, you will need to multiply them by 16 if you want to drop an item using them. Return false to stop the game from dropping the tile's default item. Returns true by default. Please note that this hook currently only works for 1x1 tiles.
member.param: The x position in tile coordinates.
The y position in tile coordinates.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.CanKillTile(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Allows you to determine whether or not the tile at the given coordinates can be hit by anything. Returns true by default. blockDamaged currently has no use.
member.param: The x position in tile coordinates.
The y position in tile coordinates.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.KillTile(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean@,System.Boolean@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Allows you to determine what happens when the tile at the given coordinates is killed or hit with a pickaxe. Fail determines whether the tile is mined, effectOnly makes it so that only dust is created, and noItem stops items from dropping.
member.param: The x position in tile coordinates.
The y position in tile coordinates.
If true, the tile won't be mined
If true, only the dust visuals will happen
If true, the corrsponding item won't drop

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.NearbyEffects(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Allows you to make things happen when this tile is within a certain range of the player (around the same range water fountains and music boxes work). The closer parameter is whether or not the tile is within the range at which aesthetics like monoliths and music boxes and clocks work. It is false for campfires and heart lanterns.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.GetTorchLuck(Terraria.Player)
member.summary: Only called for torches, when there is one nearby. Use this to contribute to vanilla torch luck calculations. Typical return values are 1f for a torch in its biome, 0.5f for a weak positive torch, -1f for a torch in an opposing biome, and -0.5f for a weak negative torch.
member.param: Main.LocalPlayer

Main.LocalPlayer

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.SetSpriteEffects(System.Int32,System.Int32,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteEffects@)
member.summary: Allows you to determine whether or not the tile will draw itself flipped in the world.
member.param: The x position in tile coordinates.
The y position in tile coordinates.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.SetDrawPositions(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32@,System.Int32@,System.Int32@,System.Int16@,System.Int16@)
member.summary:
Allows you to customize the position in which this tile is drawn. Width refers to the width of one frame of the tile, offsetY refers to how many pixels below its actual position the tile should be drawn, height refers to the height of one frame of the tile.
By default the values will be set to the values you give this tile's TileObjectData. If this tile has no TileObjectData then they will default to 16, 0, and 16, respectively.
tileFrameX and tileFrameY allow you to change which frames are drawn, keeping tile.frameX/Y intact for other purposes.
member.param: The x position in tile coordinates.
The y position in tile coordinates.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.AnimateTile(System.Int32@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Allows you to animate your tile. Use frameCounter to keep track of how long the current frame has been active, and use frame to change the current frame. This is called once an update. Use AnimateIndividualTile to animate specific tile instances directly.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.AnimateIndividualTile(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Animates an individual tile. i and j are the coordinates of the Tile in question. frameXOffset and frameYOffset should be used to specify an offset from the tiles frameX and frameY. "frameYOffset = modTile.animationFrameHeight * Main.tileFrame[type];" will already be set before this hook is called, taking into account the TileID-wide animation set via AnimateTile. Use this hook for off-sync animations (lightning bug in a bottle), temporary animations (trap chests), or TileEntities to achieve unique animation behaviors without having to manually draw the tile via PreDraw.
member.param: The tile type.
The x position in tile coordinates.
The y position in tile coordinates.
The offset to frameX.
The offset to frameY.

member.summary: Allows you to make stuff happen whenever the tile at the given coordinates is drawn. For example, creating dust or changing the color the tile is drawn in. SpecialDraw will only be called if coordinates are added using Main.instance.TilesRenderer.AddSpecialLegacyPoint here.
member.param: The x position in tile coordinates.
The y position in tile coordinates.
Various information about the tile that is being drawn, such as color, framing, glow textures, etc.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModTile.UnlockChest(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int16@,System.Int32@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Allows customization of how a chest unlock is accomplished. By default, frameXAdjustment will be -36, shifting the frameX over to the left by 1 chest style. If your chests are in a different order, adjust frameXAdjustment accordingly. This hook is called on the client, and if successful will be called on the server and other clients as the action is synced. Make sure that the logic is consistent and not dependent on local player data.
member.param: The x position in tile coordinates.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.ModWaterStyle.GetRainVariant
member.summary:
Return the variant of rain used. Equal to the offset in the rain texture divided by four.
Vanilla rain has three variants per biome, and so vanilla variants range from 0 to 3 * Main.maxLiquidTextures.
Default is a random number from 0 to 2, which creates normal vanilla forest biome rain.

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.MusicLoader.AddMusicBox(Terraria.ModLoader.Mod,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Allows you to tie a music ID, and item ID, and a tile ID together to form a music box.
When music with the given ID is playing, equipped music boxes have a chance to change their ID to the given item type.
When an item with the given item type is equipped, it will play the music that has musicSlot as its ID.
When a tile with the given type and Y-frame is nearby, if its X-frame is >= 36, it will play the music that has musicSlot as its ID.
member.param: The music slot.
The music slot.
Type of the item.
Type of the tile.
The tile frame y.
member.exception: Cannot assign music box to vanilla music id. or The provided music id does not exist. or Cannot assign music box to a vanilla item id. or The provided item id does not exist. or Cannot assign music box to a vanilla tile id. or The provided tile id does not exist
The provided music id has already been assigned a music box. or The provided item id has already been assigned a music. or Y-frame must be divisible by 36

The player that this NPC is spawning around. For convenience, here are the player zones, which are also useful for determining NPC spawn: (ZoneGranite, ZoneMarble, ZoneHive, ZoneGemCave are not actually proper spawning related checks, they are for visuals only (RGB), determined by the backwall type)
ZoneDungeon
ZoneCorrupt
ZoneHallow
ZoneMeteor
ZoneJungle
ZoneSnow
ZoneCrimson
ZoneWaterCandle
ZonePeaceCandle
ZoneTowerSolar
ZoneTowerVortex
ZoneTowerNebula
ZoneTowerStardust
ZoneDesert
ZoneGlowshroom
ZoneUndergroundDesert
ZoneSkyHeight
ZoneOverworldHeight
ZoneDirtLayerHeight
ZoneRockLayerHeight
ZoneUnderworldHeight
ZoneBeach
ZoneRain
ZoneSandstorm
ZoneOldOneArmy
ZoneGraveyard

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.StatModifier.op_Addition(Terraria.ModLoader.StatModifier,System.Single)
member.summary: By using the add operator, the supplied additive modifier is combined with the existing modifiers. For example, adding 0.12f would be equivalent to a typical 12% damage boost. For 99% of effects used in the game, this approach is used.
member.param: The additive modifier to add, where 0.01f is equivalent to 1%

member.name: M:Terraria.ModLoader.StatModifier.op_Subtraction(Terraria.ModLoader.StatModifier,System.Single)
member.summary: By using the subtract operator, the supplied subtractive modifier is combined with the existing modifiers. For example, subtracting 0.12f would be equivalent to a typical 12% damage decrease. For 99% of effects used in the game, this approach is used.
member.param: The additive modifier to subtract, where 0.01f is equivalent to 1%

member.summary: The multiply operator applies a multiplicative effect to the resulting multiplicative modifier. This effect is very rarely used, typical effects use the add operator.
member.param: The factor by which the multiplicative modifier is scaled

member.summary: This class serves as a way to store information about a line of tooltip for an item. You will create and manipulate objects of this class if you use the ModifyTooltips hook.
